 011: ################################################
 012: # Basic how to:
 013: # Use cdef int, cdef float, cdef char*, etc for all varaibles that are c typed (except function args).
 014: #   Also do it to the "i" in "for i in range(...)" loops, etc.
 015: #   Use object for Python structures.
 016: #   Use def for functions you call from python, but reamamber: each call to def is slow.
 017: #       Use cpdef if you are callind functions from inner loops and python.
 018: #
 019: # Use libc.math for native math.
 020: #
 021: # Common errors, how to debug them, and why they occur:
 022: # "cdef statement not allowed here"
 023: #     Don't define variables inside loops, etc. Only at the root of the class or functions.
 024: #     Python variables defined ina loop are useable outside of said loop, but not for C.
 025: #     These two different systems are incompatable.
 026: #  "Cannot convert 'xyzyx' to Python object"
 027: #     cdef xyz ex
 028: #     x = 1; # woops spelled ex wrong!
 029: #     Python thinks x is you defining a new variable,
 030: #     which is a python variable since there is no cdef type info.
 031: #     But c and python don't interconvert for free.
 032: #  The file is HUGE (slow probably as well) and has lots as __Pyx_PyObject_ calls, __Pyx_GOTREF, etc.
 033: #    Did you cdef all types, ESPICALLY LOOP INDEXES (loop indexes don't throw an error)?
 034: #    Do you use a self.variable that is not defined (look for where this mob of calls is)?
 035: #    Did you disable bounds and wrap checking? (Relativly less important, but nested arrays take a big hit b/c where are lengths stored?).
 036: #    Are you using python's math instead of libc.math?
 037: #    A factor of 10 or so is normal (all the comments and longer variable names), plus 500 lines beginning and 1500 lines at end.
 038: #    Case study this file: 8000 lines -> 4000 lines and about 7 times faster compile!
 039: #    cython life.pyx -a is useful to see where python interaciton is.
 040: #  Bounds checks not working on arrays:
 041: #    Use numpy arrays (more syntax and may be slower due to overhead).
 042: #    Do what the C coders are doing.
 043: ################################################
 044: 
 045: ################################################
 046: # Writing and debugging (chunks with static chunks disabled):
 047: # About 5 hours to write initial code (no oascilator detection).
 048: #
 049: # Debug phase 1 (3 hours): Making sure that it is using antive code and not sneaking in python objects.
 050: #     This also removed run-time AttributeErrors.
 051: #
 052: # Debug phase 2 (2 hours): Make sure it is right for a single chunk.
 053: #     Why did it segfault when all the safeties are enabled?
 054: #       Oh, they don't be smart and store the lenght of an array (i.e. as the first element(s) and shift all your indexes up one).
 055: #       Special feature: memory errors can cause segfaults at the termination of the program.
 056: #     Side effect: helps discover errors involving more than one chunk.
 057: #
 058: # Debug phase 3 (2 hours): multible chunks.
 059: #   Some simple array errors, looking at the pattern animate is good enough.
 060: #   Varying parameters widely helped detect harder-to-find bugs.
 061: #
 062: # Debug phase 4 (15 min): does the optimization for static chunks work:
 063: #   This is very, very short!
 064: #
 065: # Coding phase 2A: Short-period oscillation optimization.
 066: #   1 hr thinking. 1 hr core coding. 1.5 hour debugging.
 067: #       refactoring added an extra hour, not including debugging.
 068: # Coding phase 2B: Numpy.
 069: #   About 2 hr and 0.5 hr debugging, most fo the time learning numpy in the first place.
 070: #

 076:     # the spaceship travells in the + X direction, dead boundary conditions.
 077:     # For now the y has wrap-around boundary conditions.
 078: 
 079:     # The field is broken into chunks that are individually on or off depending whether
 080:     # there is any active pattern in the region vs stable (short-period oscilations are also covered).
 081:     # total size = (chunkDiam * chunksX, chunkDiam * chunksY).
 082: 
 083:     cdef int** state # current state. Note: The optimization algoryhtim does not save memory.
 084:     cdef int** nextstate # temp buffer for the next cell state, alive or dead.
 085:         # note: unwrapped as per matlab arrays.
 086:     cdef int* active # 1 = active. -globalPeriod = inactive. >-globalPeriod>=0 is the countdown (see below).
 087: 
 088:     # sizes set when the class if built:
 089:     cdef int chunkDiam # size per chunk.
 090:     cdef int chunksX # number of chunks.
 091:     cdef int chunksY
 092: 
 093:     ## Oscellation stuff:
 094:     cdef unsigned int time # current time in the simultion, increases by one at the end of each step. Overflows/wraparounds don't cause problems.
 095:     cdef int globalPeriod # The period for which we check for oscilations.
 096:                             # This must be <= the chunk size, and should be a highly composite number like 12 for a 16x16 chunk.
 097: 
 098:     cdef int** referenceState # The reference state used for oscilation checks. Set to state every globalPeriod steps.
 099: 
 100:     # Extracting the pattern at intermediate times means that we must
 101:     cdef int** patternOutputBuffer # Temp for running patterns.
 102:     cdef int** patternOutputBuffer1 # Temp for running patterns.
 103:
